author: Josh Bowman
content: Ok so wife is away this week and I’m just working non stop. Then I was like… hey I should use this opportunity to get the house super dirty and build a full back wall bass trap like I’ve been meaning to. Then… you know your shooting stuff in rew, and your like, hey I wonder what it looks like without my big desk. Then you move the desk and it’s insanely better looking on the REW graph. Then you realize you have some old wood and a closet shelf that was gonna get tossed so you make a tiny desk and spend (waste?) 15 hours over the weekend that should have been spent on mixing renovating the studio room and moving things and taking measurements till you don’t know what a anything even sounds like anymore . Anyway I feel like a Total psychopath because this is what I did Friday and Saturday all day and night. Desk is obviously in progress and I need to figure out a shelf for the hilo etc. thinking off to the side and low so I can reach it easily but it’s not reflecting stuff. Also the back wall frame is full of pink fluffy now and covered in interm fabric till I figure out what I want it too like like.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: No, it's not like sonarworks. I don't correct for furniture. I correct the speakers themselves, broad stroke room EQ, and preference EQ. As long as you didn't move the speakers or listening positiong by more than a foot, it's not going to change the calibration

author: cian riordan
content: I think the attack wall solves the problem for people that can't build their room from scratch. As someone that just built a studio, building fake walls with insulation & membranes tucked behind aint cheap. And it's permanent. Having tube traps (or the ASC pressure traps, or whatever they are) are not a panacea -- but rather a scalable, portable method of getting an untreated room in the ballpark. I've found with tube traps that more is not necessarily better and you just don't know till you get in there and shoot it. My friend Andrew Maury raves about his. He's gets amazing results and he loves moving around his setup every few months just because he likes tweaking... and the attack wall allows him to do this. So -- if you're building a studio from the ground up, there are absolutely better options. But if you're hopping around from space to space and don't feel like spending $10-15k on framing, fabric, rockwool, & building limp mass membranes... these are a terrific option.

author: Eric Martin

author: masteredbyjack
content:
First, congrats!! That’s amazing.

Honestly and truly try to hire the Unf*ck crew if you are thinking of doing something like this. Of course I am sorta biased because I did (and my project was not building a completely new structure but still decently involved in a new house we bought) but I promise you they saved me so much time, headache and made my investment absolutely worth it.

And it’s much more about the trade-offs and things they are so good at helping with than just an acoustics plan. For instance, in my case they talked me out of buying more expensive speakers and we put that into the room treatment and finishing it to be a wonderful space to work. At the time I just trusted their experience but now that it’s done I see the wisdom in it. So regardless if you work with them please consider all the trade-offs, both short term and long!

author: cian riordan
content: Completely dependent on the size of your cloud. Getting that first ceiling reflection is key. Once you have that sorted, I would base other movements on measurements. Moving cloud forward/backwards/up/down will have an effect on frequency response, even if minute.

author: ehutton21
content: It sounds more complicated than it looks as I write it. Basically drew the triangle, nudged the monitors, verified with tape measure, and it was done. But it saved me massive headaches.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I did! Under guidance of Ruairi and the unf*ck crew who advised. I know essentially nothing I just followed.

My basement was a bit smaller (about 13 feet by 30 feet) and was unfinished, so that was beneficial since I could stuff the ceiling, walls, finish off with non-drywall acoustic material, etc, build in a fake “back wall” to get the “room” to the right dimensions needed (the studio is about half my total size of the basement but the fake back wall is essentially a rock wool holder for acoustic benefit).

I have exactly no clue if any of that is useful, or indeed beneficial to what you’re doing (it may make it worse for your purposes) but it came out great, sounds wonderful and is actually a very nice bright place to be in!

No doubt your spot will come out great too and hopefully serve the purposes you’re looking for

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
Yes, for sure! As a renter, work-from-home option, they are a dream. I think you could get better ergonomics and potentially better sound from other studio design options, but the flexibility is great. They are definitely not a magic bullet to get a “flat room” either and placement / quantity can affect things greatly. 

Andrew Maury was the one who inspired my initial purchase! He does fantastic work on them and was definitely a great resource as I was looking into them. He shared this video with Greg from Kush audio which was very convincing at the time  https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=P7pOA4eeuS0&t=72m13s

I also have friends who have had good success building diy tube traps — which can be pretty affordable.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
Interesting. 

what is the best explanation for why anything that sounds good on an NS-10 sounds good elsewhere? Is it more than just the frequency response?

author: BatMeckley
content: Exactly. And if someone is trying to go “frequency response graph is the benchmark for what makes a speaker “objectively good”” everyone who actually does this for a living has an obligation to mock that concept into oblivion.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I never said it was the frequency response that is to blame for this. I just said the frequency response is representative of the problems there. If you EQ a speaker to match that it won’t sound like an NS10 cause you won’t have all of the problems from their crossover

author: Rollmottle
content: do NS-10's have a smooth frequency response?

author: BatMeckley
content:
Up to a point. Just because a carrot is part of a stew doesn’t mean a stew is a carrot.

Atc’s don’t have ruler flat response and are hyper useful. I think part of this is that frequency response is WAY overhyped and doesn’t tell nearly as much about a speaker as people want it too pmc and genelec can both measure flat and sound ENTIRELY different. So much in the time domain and presentation and thd doesn’t show up on a graph like that. And that’s the point.

And for someone who’s trying to sell speakers to imply that is, or that NS10s are broken or objectively bad deserves all the pushback they’re getting

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: You could make a flat speaker that’s completely unusable (let’s have the tweeter fire in the other direction, put a wall between you and the speaker…) so I don’t really care to look at frequency responses other than for revealing specific problems that you know via other sources like the NS10 crossover

author: Rob Domos
content: Lmao slow down. Obviously something can be flat and still suck. All we have to do is use sonarworks on a Logitech speaker to experience that. What I’m saying is, all things being equal, not having a 5db response swing within one octave is probably desirable. Y’all getting way too pedantic haha

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Decent enough in most categories like frequency response, distortion, off axis performance, no huge problems in the crossover. Something with no clearly overlooked aspects

author: Rob Domos

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: The would depend on how the panel was built but most likely yes. I rebuilt all of my panels like that many years ago. I went through the process of measuring with REW as I "upgraded" each panel in the room and the differences were huge but unfortunately I somehow lost that file. The testing I've done since has been with smaller panels (not an entire room) so the differences you see in REW measurements are much smaller

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
About that, what's the vocabulary for describing the stability of a mic outside of pure frequency response?

The U87 AI "should" not have a bump there according to most measurements (this one is from Audio Test Kitchen)

author: chrissorem
content: I’m not a mic expert by any means but my understanding is that it all has to do with the material of the capsule and more importantly the tuning of the capsule. Every company has a different way of measuring the tuning. If it’s not to spec it can drastically change the frequency response. It’s little bit of the wild Wild West when it comes to consistency between mics. But I think the bumps are from capsule resonance. I’m sure there are more qualified people to answer this though then me

author: chris_donlin
content: I'm a big lavazza drinker - gran aroma, pre-ground - and it's pretty wild how different it tastes from my roomates drip machine vs my areopress. As i've gotten more into coffee the past year or so, it's been interesting seeing how the "sum of parts" concept applies to other things, especially music cus that's what we do. Grind size, time of brew, temperature of water, brew method, etc. Used to not buy into it, but they certainly affect the outcome. Mic, placement, preamp, quality of the source, etc. are all important too!

author: An Hero

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: @Gerhard Westphalen should we do another calibration on the miniDSP now that furniture has changed?

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: The only real exception to this is if your speakers are on the desk and then you remove the desk since that makes a huge difference as you were effectively splitting the room in 2 where the speakers were but I don't remember the last time I did a calibration like that since I'd suggest getting rid of a desk setup like that before considering DSP

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I get a lot of questions where people have moved their speakers by 2" or installed a lamp at the back of the room and want to know if we need to recalibrate... the answer is almost always no

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: How things sound and the frequency response might change but it's not something that would affect the DSP calibration in the way I do it (unlike something like sonarworks or Trinnov which is trying to fix comb filtering)
